author: Simon Robb for Metro.co.uk
title: SeaWorld announces end to killer whale shows after Tilikum’s death
text:
SeaWorld Adventure Park trainer Ken Peters looks to a killer whale during a performance at Shamu Stadium inside (Picture: AP) SeaWorld San Diego announced it is ending its killer whale show after the death of Tilikum the whale – but it’s not completely over. 
The orca made famous by Blackfish documentary died at the age of 36 on Friday.
Brave trans teen allows camera to film her gender reassignment surgery Now the show, that featured killer whales leaping high out of the Shamu Stadium pool, will have its final performances on Sunday, said SeaWorld.
Instead, a new attraction called Orca Encounter will replace it this summer.
The show is billed as an educational experience, showing how killer whales eat, communicate and navigate.
But despite years of outcry from animal rights activists, the new show will still feature whales in captivity leaping out of the water and taking cues from trainers.
People watch through glass as a killer whale swims by in a display tank at SeaWorld in San Diego (Picture: AP) Al Garver, vice president of zoological operations, told the San Diego Union-Tribune whales will still be performing their usual tricks.
Donald Trump to return Winston Churchill bust to Oval Office ‘We want to be able to demonstrate behaviors people would see in the wild with the killer whales and their abilities as a top predator in the sea. The vast majority of behaviors people have seen in our shows will be very suitable for demonstrating that.’
The park has 11 orcas, ranging in age from 2 to 52 years old.
Animal rights activists fill the room during a California Coastal Commission meeting in Long Beach, California (Picture: AP) Tilikum was bred and spent 25 years in captivity at SeaWorld.
Boy who can't speak forms unbreakable bond with deaf dog through sign language The park saw its attendance fall since the 2013 documentary Blackfish, which chronicled the life of the whale that killed a trainer during a performance in Orlando in 2010.
The company also announced that it would help develop its first SeaWorld park without orcas in Abu Dhabi.
And will be phasing out whale shows in Orlando and San Antonio.
